# SEO Audit Report for https://api.example.com/docs

---

## Executive Summary
The API documentation site is generally crawlable, but the **Auth** page (`/docs/auth`) has critical SEO issues: a missing title tag, a very short meta description, and a `noindex` directive that prevents the page from appearing in search results. Addressing these items will improve visibility and click‑through rates.

---

## On‑Page Issues
### 1. https://api.example.com/docs
| Issue | Status | Details |
|-------|--------|---------|
| Title Tag | ✅ Present | Title tag is present and within length limits. |
| Meta Description | ✅ Present (48 characters) | Acceptable length. |
| Robots Directive | ✅ `index, follow` | Allows crawling and indexing. |

### 2. https://api.example.com/docs/auth
| Issue | Status | Details |
|-------|--------|---------|
| Title Tag | ❌ Missing | Missing title tag; search engines may use URL as title. |
| Meta Description | ⚠️ Present (23 characters) | Very short; consider expanding to 120‑160 characters. |
| Robots Directive | ❌ `noindex, nofollow` | Page is blocked from indexing. |

---

## Guideline Violations
| URL | Violation | Severity | Recommendation |
|-----|-----------|----------|----------------|
| https://api.example.com/docs/auth | Noindex directive on an important documentation page | High | Remove the `noindex` directive or add a canonical link to the preferred version. |

---

## Prioritized Action List
1. **Add a concise, keyword‑rich title tag** to `/docs/auth` (High priority).
2. **Update the meta description** for `/docs/auth` to 130‑160 characters, summarizing the authentication API benefits (Medium priority).
3. **Remove the `noindex` directive** from `/docs/auth` so the page can be indexed (High priority).
4. **Run a full site speed audit** (optional next step) to ensure the pages meet Core Web Vitals.

---
